caption: Payment Spend ($ Volume) and YoY % Growth
trend_summary: The bar chart shows total payment spend volume increasing from $0.9T in 1Q22 to $1.1T in 1Q25. The year-over-year growth rate has slowed from 13% in 1Q22 to 4% in 1Q25.

caption: Payment Spend ($ and Transaction Volume) Quarterly YoY % Growth
trend_summary: The line chart illustrates the quarterly year-over-year percentage growth for both payment volume and transaction numbers. Both metrics show a declining growth trend from a peak in early 2021, stabilizing to low single-digit growth by 1Q25, where volume growth was 4% and transaction growth was 2%.

caption: 1Q25 Credit and Debit YoY % Growth
trend_summary: This bar chart displays the year-over-year growth in spend volume and transaction numbers across different categories. Travel & Entertainment saw 3% volume growth and 5% transaction growth. Services also grew strongly with 5% volume and 2% transaction growth. Gas spending declined by 4% in volume.

caption: Payment Transaction Volume 1Q25 vs. 1Q19
trend_summary: Comparing payment transaction volumes in 1Q25 to 1Q19, P2P/P2B transactions have grown by 109%. ACH/Wire and Credit/Debit transactions also grew by 52% and 27% respectively, while Cash/Check transactions declined by 39%.

caption: CET1 Ratio Drivers
trend_summary: This waterfall chart explains the change in the CET1 ratio from 11.9% at the end of 4Q24 to 11.8% at the end of 1Q25. Net income added 41 bps, while common dividends (-12 bps), RWA growth (-11 bps), share repurchases (-27 bps), and other factors (-2 bps) reduced the ratio. The final 1Q25 ratio of 11.8% is approximately 110 bps above the regulatory minimum.

caption: Total Corporation ($B)
trend_summary: Total corporate average deposits increased to $1,958B in 1Q25, up from $1,907B in 1Q24. The total rate paid decreased slightly to 1.79% in 1Q25 from 1.94% in 4Q24, while the proportion of interest-bearing deposits has been growing.

caption: Consumer Banking ($B)
trend_summary: Consumer Banking average deposits decreased to $948B in 1Q25 from $952B in 1Q24. The total rate paid was 0.61% in 1Q25, a slight decrease from 0.64% in 4Q24, but up from 0.55% in 1Q24.

caption: GWIM ($B)
trend_summary: GWIM average deposits decreased to $286B in 1Q25 from $297B in 1Q24. The total rate paid has decreased to 2.50% in 1Q25 from a peak of 2.89% in 4Q23.

caption: Global Banking ($B)
trend_summary: Global Banking average deposits increased to $575B in 1Q25 from $525B in 1Q24. The total rate paid decreased to 2.73% in 1Q25 from 3.12% in 1Q24.

caption: Total Loans and Leases ($B)
trend_summary: Total average loans and leases grew steadily from $1,048B in 1Q24 to $1,094B in 1Q25, representing a 4% year-over-year increase.

caption: Total Loans and Leases by Portfolio ($B)
trend_summary: The portfolio mix shows Consumer loans at $462B and Commercial loans at $632B in 1Q25. Both segments have grown over the past year, with commercial loans showing slightly stronger growth.

caption: Loans and Leases in Business Segments ($B)
trend_summary: By business segment, Global Markets showed the strongest YoY growth at +19% reaching $160B. Global Banking grew 6% to $232B, while Consumer Banking and GWIM both grew 1% to $315B and $379B respectively.

caption: Total Loans and Leases by Product ($B)
trend_summary: By product, U.S. commercial loans ($412B), consumer credit cards ($123B), and commercial real estate ($139B) are the largest components. Most loan categories show modest growth over the past year.

caption: Net Interest Income (FTE, $B)
trend_summary: Net interest income (FTE basis) has been increasing, reaching $14.6B in 1Q25 from $14.2B in 1Q24. GAAP NII also rose to $14.4B in 1Q25.

caption: Net Interest Yield (FTE)
trend_summary: Reported net interest yield was 1.99% in 1Q25, flat compared to 1Q24. The net interest yield excluding Global Markets (GM) has been trending upwards, reaching 2.47% in 1Q25.

caption: Net Interest Income Mix (FTE, $B)
trend_summary: The bar chart shows total FTE NII increasing to $14.6B in 1Q25. The component from Global Markets (GM NII) has been relatively volatile, while NII excluding GM has been more stable, standing at $13.4B in 1Q25.

caption: Net Interest Income Outlook 1Q25 to 4Q25
trend_summary: This waterfall chart projects the change in Net Interest Income (FTE basis) from $14.6B in 1Q25 to a range of $15.5B-$15.7B in 4Q25. Positive drivers include day count (~$250MM), fixed-rate asset repricing (~$550MM), Global Markets NII (~$200MM), and other growth/mix effects (~$350MM-$550MM). This is partially offset by an expected negative impact from interest rate cuts of ~$450MM.

caption: Total Noninterest Expense ($B)
trend_summary: Total noninterest expense was $17.8B in 1Q25, an increase from $16.8B in 4Q24 and $17.2B in 1Q24. The 1Q25 expense consists of $10.9B in compensation and benefits and $6.9B in other expenses. Prior quarters included an FDIC special assessment, which was absent in 1Q25.

caption: Efficiency Ratio
trend_summary: The efficiency ratio was 65% in 1Q25. It fluctuated over the past year, with a high of 67% in 4Q24 and a low of 64% in 1Q24 and 2Q24.

caption: Net Charge-offs ($MM)
trend_summary: Net charge-offs have been relatively stable over the past five quarters, standing at $1,452MM in 1Q25. The net charge-off ratio has also remained stable, at 0.54% in 1Q25.

caption: Provision for Credit Losses ($MM)
trend_summary: The provision for credit losses was $1,480MM in 1Q25, a slight increase from $1,452MM in 4Q24 but higher than the $1,319MM in 1Q24.

caption: Consumer Net Charge-offs ($MM)
trend_summary: Consumer net charge-offs increased to $1,119MM in 1Q25 from $1,028MM in 1Q24, driven by credit card charge-offs. The consumer NCO ratio also increased, reaching 0.98% in 1Q25.

caption: Commercial Net Charge-offs ($MM)
trend_summary: Commercial net charge-offs decreased to $333MM in 1Q25 from $470MM in 1Q24. The commercial NCO ratio has also declined to 0.22% in 1Q25 from 0.32% a year ago, driven by lower C&I charge-offs.

caption: Loan Mix
trend_summary: The loan mix has shifted from 4Q09 to 1Q25. In 4Q09, the $1,003B portfolio was 67% Consumer and 33% Commercial. By 1Q25, the $1,111B portfolio became 58% Commercial and 42% Consumer, indicating a significant rebalancing towards commercial lending.

caption: Consumer Loan Portfolio ($B)
trend_summary: The consumer loan portfolio composition changed significantly from $675B in 4Q09 to $468B in 1Q25. Residential mortgage and home equity lending decreased dramatically (e.g., home equity down 83%), while consumer credit card and other consumer loans saw more moderate changes.

caption: Commercial Loan Portfolio ($B)
trend_summary: The commercial loan portfolio grew from $328B in 4Q09 to $643B in 1Q25. U.S. commercial loans nearly doubled, and other commercial loans grew approximately fivefold, indicating strong expansion in these areas.

caption: Federal Reserve Stress Test Loan Loss Rates (%)
trend_summary: The line chart shows the nine-quarter severely adverse scenario loss rates from the Federal Reserve Stress Test for Bank of America (BAC) and three peers from 2013 to 2024. BAC's loss rate has generally been below its peers, and in 2024 it was 5.5%, lower than Peer 1 (6.3%), Peer 2 (7.6%), and Peer 3 (6.0%).

caption: Consumer Loan Portfolio Average Balance
trend_summary: The bar chart shows the average balance of the total consumer loan portfolio at $462B. This is broken down into Residential Mortgage ($229B), Credit Card ($100B), Consumer Vehicle Lending ($54B), Securities-Based Lending ($52B), and Home Equity ($26B).

caption: Total Revenue ($B)
trend_summary: Total revenue in Consumer Banking was $10.5B in 1Q25, slightly down from $10.6B in 4Q24 but up from $10.2B in 1Q24. Net interest income has been the dominant component, at $8.5B in 1Q25.

caption: Total Expense ($B) and Efficiency
trend_summary: Total expense increased to $5.8B in 1Q25 from $5.6B in 4Q24. The efficiency ratio increased to 56% in 1Q25 from 53% in 4Q24.

caption: Average Deposits ($B)
trend_summary: Average deposits have remained relatively stable, totaling $948B in 1Q25. The mix between low-interest/noninterest checking and other deposits has also been consistent over the past year.

caption: Average Loans and Leases ($B)
trend_summary: Average loans and leases were stable at $315B in 1Q25. The composition has been consistent, with residential mortgage ($115B) and consumer credit card ($97B) being the largest components.

caption: Consumer Investment Assets ($B) and Accounts (MM)
trend_summary: Consumer investment assets decreased to $498B in 1Q25 from a peak of $518B in 4Q24. The number of accounts remained stable at 4.0MM.

caption: Digital Users and Households
trend_summary: Digital adoption continues to grow, with 59 million verified users and 49 million active users in 1Q25. Household adoption reached 78%.

caption: Digital Channel Usage
trend_summary: Digital channel usage (desktop and mobile sessions) increased to 3,972 million in 1Q25, up from 2,748 million in 1Q22, showing a steady upward trend.

caption: Digitally-Enabled Sales
trend_summary: The number of digitally-enabled sales reached 1,976,000 in 1Q25, with digital sales making up 65% of total sales, a significant increase from 53% in 1Q23.

caption: Erica Active Users and Interactions
trend_summary: Erica active users grew to 19.9 million in 1Q25, with interactions reaching 175.5 million, indicating increasing engagement with the digital assistant.

caption: Person-to-Person Payments (Zelle)
trend_summary: Zelle usage has shown strong growth, with 23.9 million active users in 1Q25. The number of transactions rose to 416 million, with a total volume of $150B.

caption: Zelle vs. Cash and Checks (MM)
trend_summary: The volume of Zelle sent transactions (263 million) surpassed cash withdrawn & checks written (202 million) in 1Q25, with Zelle transactions being 1.3 times higher.

caption: Average Deposits ($B)
trend_summary: Average deposits in GWIM were $286B in 1Q25, down from $297B in 1Q24. There has been a shift from sweep deposits to bank deposits over the year.

caption: Average Loans and Leases ($B)
trend_summary: Average loans and leases grew steadily to $232B in 1Q25 from $219B in 1Q24, with growth across all lending categories including securities-based lending and custom lending.

caption: Total Revenue ($B)
trend_summary: Total revenue increased to $6.0B in 1Q25 from $5.6B in 1Q24, driven by growth in asset management fees, which rose to $3.7B.

caption: Client Balances ($B)
trend_summary: Total client balances were $4,157B in 1Q25, up from $3,973B in 1Q24. The growth was driven by increases in AUM and loans/leases, despite a slight dip from 4Q24.

caption: Digital Households / Relationships
trend_summary: The number of digitally engaged households/relationships grew to 759,000 in 1Q25, with the digital adoption rate increasing to 87% from 81% in 1Q22.

caption: Digital Channel Adoption
trend_summary: Digital channel adoption has reached 81% in 1Q25, with mobile adoption at 64% and online adoption steady. Overall adoption has increased from 75% in 1Q22.

caption: eDelivery
trend_summary: eDelivery adoption has consistently increased, reaching 82% in 1Q25, up from 74% in 1Q22.

caption: Erica Interactions (MM)
trend_summary: Erica interactions have grown steadily, reaching 3.5 million in 1Q25 from 1.8 million in 1Q22, indicating increased use of the digital assistant.

caption: Person-to-Person Payments (Zelle)
trend_summary: Zelle transaction volume has grown, reaching $4.2B in 1Q25 from $1.2B in 1Q22, with a corresponding increase in the number of transactions.

caption: Check Deposits
trend_summary: The majority of check deposits are now digital. In 1Q25, 68% of check deposits were made via digital channels and 7% via ATM, while only 24% were physical.

caption: Average Deposits ($B)
trend_summary: Average deposits in Global Banking increased to $575B in 1Q25 from $526B in 1Q24. The proportion of noninterest-bearing deposits has decreased from 31% to 27% over the same period.

caption: Average Loans and Leases ($B)
trend_summary: Average loans and leases increased to $379B in 1Q25 from $374B in 1Q24, with modest growth in both commercial and corporate lending.

caption: Total Revenue ($B)
trend_summary: Total revenue for Global Banking was $6.0B in 1Q25, flat compared to 1Q24. The composition shows net interest income at $3.2B, service charges at $1.0B, and IB fees at $0.8B.

caption: Total Corporation IB Fees ($MM)
trend_summary: Total corporate IB fees were $1,523MM in 1Q25, down from $1,568MM in 1Q24. Debt fees ($942MM) were the largest component, followed by advisory ($272MM) and equity ($384MM).

caption: Relationship Client Adoption %
trend_summary: Digital adoption among relationship clients in Global Banking has remained high and stable, at 86% in 1Q25, consistent with previous quarters.

caption: Mobile App Sign-ins (K)
trend_summary: Mobile app sign-ins for Global Banking clients have shown strong and consistent growth, increasing from 931,000 in 1Q22 to 2,154,000 in 1Q25.

caption: CashPro App Payments
trend_summary: Payments through the CashPro app have seen substantial growth. The value of payments increased to $222B in 1Q25 from $136B in 1Q22, while the volume of payments grew to 4.3 million from 2.4 million over the same period.

caption: Erica Interactions on CashPro Chat (K)
trend_summary: Erica interactions on CashPro Chat have increased from 29,700 in 2Q24 to 33,500 in 1Q25, indicating growing engagement since its integration.

caption: Proactive Alerts and Insights (MM)
trend_summary: The volume of proactive alerts and insights sent to clients has steadily increased, reaching 23.4 million in 1Q25, up from 17.5 million in 1Q22.

caption: Capital Markets Digital Bond Orders (%)
trend_summary: The percentage of U.S. Dollar Investment Grade Debt investor bond orders processed digitally has surged, reaching 37% in 1Q25, up significantly from 5% in 1Q22 and 23% in 4Q24.

caption: 1Q25 Global Markets Revenue Mix (excl. net DVA)
trend_summary: The revenue mix for Global Markets in 1Q25 is dominated by U.S. / Canada, which accounts for 62% of the revenue, while International operations contribute the remaining 38%.

caption: 1Q25 Total FICC Sales and Trading Revenue Mix (excl. net DVA)
trend_summary: The FICC sales and trading revenue in 1Q25 is split between Credit/Other, making up 54% of the total, and Macro products, which account for the remaining 46%.

caption: Total Sales and Trading Revenue (excl. net DVA) ($B)
trend_summary: Total sales and trading revenue (excluding net DVA) has grown to $5.6B in 1Q25, up from $4.7B in 1Q22. Both FICC and Equities have shown growth over the period, with FICC at $3.5B and Equities at $2.2B in 1Q25.

caption: Average Trading-Related Assets ($B) and VaR ($MM)
trend_summary: Average trading-related assets have increased to $668B in 1Q25 from $596B in 1Q22. The Average Value at Risk (VaR) has been more volatile, peaking at $103MM in 1Q23 and standing at $91MM in 1Q25.
